The Myth of the Moon Rabbit

The Moon rabbit or Moon hare is a mythical figure in East Asian and indigenous American folklore, based on pareidolic interpretations that identify the dark markings on the near side of the Moon as a rabbit or hare. In East Asia, the rabbit is seen as pounding with a mortar and pestle, but the contents of the mortar differ among Chinese, Japanese, Korean and Vietnamese folklore. In Chinese folk... Read more.

AI and Animals

In the 1970s a young gorilla known as Koko drew worldwide attention with her ability to use human sign language. But skeptics maintain that Koko and other animals that “learned” to speak (including chimpanzees and dolphins) could not truly understand what they were “saying”—and that trying to make other species use human language, in which symbols represent things that may not be physically pre... Read more.

Crocodile tears are actually very similar to our own

Most of us think of tears as a human phenomenon, part of the complex fabric of human emotion. But they’re not just for crying: All vertebrates, even reptiles and birds, have tears, which are critical for maintaining healthy eyesight. Read more.

Welcome to BLUE EARTH!

Here at BLUE EARTH we bring you animal-related content from around the world, from major news to technology. All content on this site is totally voluntary, meaning you can get news from all sorts of different perspectives from all around the world.

We currently do not have any permanent positions! As the site is run on a voluntary basis, we rely on people like you to provide content to the site. If you're interested in submitting an article, please contact us at admin@blue-earth.com and we can start your submission review process right away!

Content brought to you by BLUE EARTH (c) 2023
